content: The "Motor Donor Act" establishes a National Organ Donor Registry under the Public Health Service Act. The purposes of this subpart are to increase the number of organ and tissue donors, enhance information provided to individuals, ensure timely and accurate information on donation wishes. The subpart aims to improve organ and tissue donation information by enhancing state driver's license application processes and establishing donor registries. The subpart aims to improve organ and tissue donation information by establishing donor registries through State motor vehicle driver's license application processes. The Secretary will establish a national organ and tissue donor registry called the 'Registry' containing information of individuals who wish to be donors. The national organ and tissue donor registry, known as the 'Registry', will contain information of individuals who have expressed intent to be donors, including their name, address, date of birth, sex, height, eye color, and a unique identification number assigned by the Secretary. Coordination with states and organ procurement organizations will be established. The individual's information in the national organ and tissue donor registry includes name, address, date of birth, sex, height, eye color, and a unique identification number. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations to share existing data during the initial 2-year period after the enactment of the Motor Donor Act. During the 2-year period after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will coordinate with states to share data and provide links between the Registry and State agencies. During the 4-year period after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will coordinate with states to establish organ and tissue donor registries through the motor vehicle driver's license process and provide support to organ procurement organizations. The Motor Donor Act aims to promote organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. The Secretary will provide organ procurement organizations with 24-hour access to the Registry using assigned passwords. Staff members within the organizations must be designated to receive the password. The Motor Donor Act allows organ procurement organizations in the United States to access the Registry 24/7 using assigned passwords. Designated staff members within the organizations must receive the password to access the Registry. The Secretary will disseminate information to all U.S. citizens who filed a Federal income tax return within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Motor Donor Act requires the Secretary to distribute a pamphlet to U.S. citizens who filed a Federal income tax return within 3 years of the Act's enactment, containing information on organ and tissue donations and a website address for Registry participation. The Motor Donor Act mandates the distribution of a pamphlet to eligible citizens with details on organ and tissue donations and a website for Registry enrollment. The allocated funds shall remain available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information for organ donor program purposes to the Department of Health and Human Services upon written request. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can request disclosure of taxpayer information for contacting individuals as necessary for carrying out requirements. The disclosed information can only be used by Department of Health and Human Services employees to contact individuals for the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
